subject: Re: [junit] Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?

messageBody:
> So, is this kind of testing important enough to warrant all the effort
> it takes to write & keep up to date?
> Should we care what method got called on our mock, or even whether it
> did get called at all? Or are we really only interested in the result
> of the main method we're testing?

It depends on what your strategy is. I'd advice against "navigating"
with mocks (in order to test this branch mockA.someFlag() needs to
return 4711 and then it will go through this loop two times before so
mockA.hasNext() must return true twice and then false. After that we
setup expectations on MockB and those are the ones we /really/ care
about).

Basically, if you are /navigating/ to something that you care about.
See if you can structure your code so that you don't have to navigate.
Can you extract that chunk of logic to a separate method or class. Do
you lack an abstraction?

It is certainly not wrong to leave mocks out entirely. Lots of really
good TDD:ers do that so it's nothing to feel embarrassed about. I
personally think that mocks are handy since it gets painful so quickly
when you're on the wrong track but that is just me.

I like this story about a team evolving:
http://igorstoyanov.blogspot.com/2005/10/stubs-or-mocks-state-or-behavior_30.html

Maybe a team has to go through that evolution? Maybe your team evolves
differently? The important thing is to keep looking for and
implementing improvements.

/J
